title: Graham v. State
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->




THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Eric A. Graham, Appellant,
				v.
				State, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Darlington County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-498
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 5, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Eric A. Graham, pro se Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Karen C. Ratigan, Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia for
  Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Eric A. Graham appeals the dismissal of
  his petition for writ of habeas corpus. Â We affirm.[1]
FACTS
  AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Graham
  was convicted of murder and sentenced to life in prison by Judge Paul M. Burch
  in August of 1998.Â  An Anders appeal was filed and dismissed.Â  Graham
  then filed an application for post-conviction relief, and that application was
  dismissed.Â  His subsequent writ of certiorari to the South Carolina Supreme
  Court was denied.Â  Graham filed another application for post-conviction relief
  which was also dismissed.Â  Graham then filed a petition for writ of habeas corpus
  which was dismissed by Judge Burch acting in his capacity as chief
  administrative judge.
Graham
  appeals the dismissal of his petition for writ of habeas corpus.Â  The focus of
  his appeal is on Judge Burchâ€™s failure to recuse himself from ruling on the petition
  as he was the presiding judge at his trial.Â  Graham also argues in a very
  cursory fashion that his petition is meritorious.Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Graham
  contends Judge Burch was required to recuse himself from considering the
  dismissal of his petition for writ of habeas corpus because of his prior involvement
  with Grahamâ€™s case.Â  We disagree.Â  
Canon 3(E)(1) of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Rule 501, South
  Carolina Appellate Court Rules, provides
  that â€œ[a] judge shall
  disqualify himself or herself in a proceeding in which the judgeâ€™s impartiality
  might reasonably be questioned.â€Â  This includes instances where â€œthe judge has a personal bias or
  prejudice concerning a party or a partyâ€™s lawyer, or personal knowledge of
  disputed evidentiary facts concerning the proceeding.â€Â  Code of Judicial
  Conduct, Canon 3(E)(1)(a), CJC, Rule 501, SCACR.Â  However, the standard for
  establishing such prejudice is high.

	The alleged bias must stem from an
  extrajudicial source and result in a decision based on other than what the
  judge learned from his participation in the case. It is not enough for a party
  to allege bias; a party seeking disqualification of a judge must show some
  evidence of bias or prejudice. When no evidence is presented other than claimed
  â€œadverseâ€ rulings by the judge, the judge is not required to recuse himself.
	

Reading v. Ball, 291 S.C. 492,
  494, 354 S.E.2d 397, 398 (Ct. App. 1987) (citations omitted).Â  
In the instant case, Graham has failed to put forth any evidence
  that calls Judge Burchâ€™s impartiality into question.Â  Furthermore, Judge Burch
  was only acting in his capacity as chief administrative judge when he dismissed
  Grahamâ€™s Petition.Â  Judge Burch performed a ministerial function dismissing the
  case on procedural grounds because of Grahamâ€™s filing the petition in circuit
  court as opposed to the original jurisdiction of the South Carolina Supreme
  Court.Â  See Keeler v. Mauney, 330 S.C. 568, 571, 500 S.E.2d 123,
  124 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œA person is procedurally barred from petitioning the
  circuit court for a writ of habeas corpus where the matter alleged is one which
  could have been raised in a PCR application.Â  Â Furthermore, if a person is
  procedurally barred, his only means of obtaining state habeas corpus relief is
  to file a petition in the original jurisdiction of the Supreme Court.â€).Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Because there is no evidence of bias on the part of Judge Burch or
  prejudice to Graham, the dismissal of Grahamâ€™s petition is
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1]  This case was decided without oral argument
  pursuant to SCACR 215.

title: Furtick v. SCDC
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->




THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				James Furtick, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina
      Department of Corrections, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marlboro County
Â John M. Baxley, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No.Â Â  2008-UP-499
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 5, 2008
DISMISSED


	
		
			
				James Furtick, pro se Appellant.
				Robert Wesley Jacobs, South Carolina Department of Corrections, of
  Columbia for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  James Furtick appeals the refusal of the
  Marlboro County Clerk of Court to file his petition for writ of mandamus.Â  We
  dismiss.[1]
FACTS
  AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Furtick
  attempted to file a petition for writ of mandamus with the Clerk of Court in Marlboro County where he is incarcerated.Â  The filing was not accepted, but was returned to
  Furtick with a notation indicating that his filing was not in compliance with
  â€œRule 3.â€Â  The notation is signed by a circuit court judge.[2] Furtick attempted to file the petition again, but the documents were returned
  to him with a post-it note affixed advising him to â€œ[f]ile in the county of
  conviction.â€Â  Furtick appeals the failure of the Clerk to file his petition. 
LAW/ANALYSIS
The
  issue of the Clerkâ€™s failure to file Furtickâ€™s petition is not appealable.Â 
  Even if we assume the notation by the circuit court judge constituted a ruling,
  it does not appear to fall within the parameters of those rulings which are
  reviewable by this court.[3]Â 
  The ruling is not a final judgment, and it does not necessarily affect the
  judgment or involve the merits of the petition.Â  The ruling does not affect a
  substantial right, nor does it involve an injunction or the appointment of a
  receiver.Â  All Furtick must do is file his petition in the proper county.Â  We
  must assume that if he does so, the petition will be considered on the merits
  and only then will it become a final judgment eligible for review by this
  Court. 
However,
  it is imperative to note that the instruction for Furtick to file his petition
  in the county of conviction is erroneous.Â  â€œA writ of mandamus is used to
  compel a public officer to perform a ministerial duty or act the officer
  refuses to perform.â€Â  Richland County v. Kaiser, 351 S.C.
  89, 94, 567 S.E.2d 260, 262 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  In this case, Furtick seeks to
  compel officials with the South Carolina Department of Corrections to perform
  certain behavioral assessment that could entitle him to a reduction in his
  sentence.Â  Because they seek to require the action of the respondent, it
  logically follows that such petitions are to be filed in the county where the
  respondent resides.Â  See State ex rel. Kirven v.
    Scarborough, 70 S.C. 288, 288, 49 S.E. 860, 861 (1904) (â€œ[A]n issue in
  mandamus proceedings should be tried where the respondent resides.â€).Â  In the
  instant case, the correctional officers who work directly with Furtick are
  employed in Marlboro County where he is incarcerated.Â  However, the
  headquarters for SCDC, a state institution, is in Richland County.Â  Therefore, it would certainly be appropriate for Furtick to file his petition there.[4]Â  
SCDC
  also contends they are not a proper party in this appeal.Â  Because the issue is
  disposed of on the basis of appealability, we decline to address this
  argument.Â  See Whiteside v. Cherokee County Sch. Dist. No. One,
  311 S.C. 335, 340, 428 S.E.2d 886, 889 (1993) (holding the appellate court need
  not address remaining issues when resolution of prior issue is dispositive).
Based on all of the foregoing, this appeal is
DISMISSED.
ANDERSON,
  WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1]  This case was decided without oral argument
  pursuant to SCACR 215.
[2]  Furtick maintains the notation was made by
  Judge John M. Baxley.Â  It is not entirely clear from the record who signed the
  note, but that is not relevant to the disposition of the case.
[3]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (Supp.
  2007) addresses appellate jurisdiction and provides for jurisdiction over an
  appeal from the following:
(1) A final
  judgment in a court of common pleas or general sessions; 
  (2) On appeal from any such final judgment, any intermediate order or decree â€˜necessarily
  affecting the judgment [and] not before appealed fromâ€;
  (3) An intermediate judgment, order, or decree of a court of common pleas or
  general sessions â€œinvolving the meritsâ€;
  (4) â€œAn order affecting a substantial right when such order 
(a) in effect
  determines the action and prevents a judgment from which an appeal might be
  taken or discontinues the action; 
  (b) grants or refuses a new trial; or 
  (c) strikes out an answer or any part thereof or any pleading in any action;â€ 
  (5) A final order â€œaffecting a substantial rightâ€ made in a â€œspecial
  proceedingâ€ or in a summary proceeding after judgment; and 
  (6) An interlocutory order or decree in a court of common pleas which (a)
  grants, continues, modifies, or refuses an injunction or (b) grants, continues,
  modifies, or refuses the appointment of a receiver. 
[4]  It is arguable that Marlboro County is also an appropriate place for filing under the circumstances.Â  However, since Richland County is the headquarters for SCDC it would clearly be correct for Furtick to
  file the petition there.

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-500
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Chief Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, South Carolina
  Commission on Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant. 
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior

PER CURIAM: Roddrekius
  M. Grimmage appeals from his conviction
  for first-degree burglary, arguing the trial court erred by failing to direct a
  verdict in his favor.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authority: State v. Adams,
  354 S.C. 361, 380, 580 S.E.2d 785, 795 (Ct. App. 2003) (holding arguments not
  raised to and ruled upon by the trial court are not preserved for appellate
  review, and a defendant may not argue one ground below and another on appeal).
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this
  case without oral argument pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Kevin L. Brown, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Roger M. Young, Circuit Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-501
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 5, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Deborah Shupe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe,
  Jr.,Â  of Summerville, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Kevin L. Brown appeals his
  conviction for possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine.Â  Brown
  contends the court erred in allowing the State to amend his indictment because
  the amendment changed the nature of the charge against him.Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and
  the following authority: State v. Gentry, 363 S.C. 93, 102-03, 610 S.E.2d 494, 500 (2005) (holding the indictment
  is a notice document which is sufficient if (1) it states the offense charged
  with sufficient certainty and particularity to enable the court to know what
  judgment to pronounce, and for the defendant to know what he is called upon to
  answer, and (2) it apprises the defendant of the elements of the offense
  intended to be charged). 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Helen P.
      Johnson, Respondent,
				v.
				Mamie Jackson, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
Â Joseph M. Strickland, Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No.Â  2008-UP-502
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 5, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Mamie Jackson, of Columbia, pro se, for Appellant.
				Leo Dryer, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Helen Johnson brought suit
  against Mamie Jackson for Jacksonâ€™s breach of a land purchase agreement.Â Â  The
  circuit court found Jackson in default, and referred the matter to the
  master-in-equity.Â  Jackson now contends the master did not have jurisdiction
  because the order of reference was based on an erroneous grant of default.Â  We
  affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authority: Winesett v. Winesett, 287 S.C. 332, 334, 338 S.E.2d 340, 341 (1985) (â€œ[A] default judgment
  may not be appealed to [the supreme court].Â  The proper procedure for
  challenging a default judgment is to move the trial court to set aside the
  judgment pursuant to Rule 60(b), SCRCP.â€); Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330
  S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised
    for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon
  by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).
AFFIRMED.[1]
HEARN, C.J., and HUFF, and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.Â  


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM: Avis Shumate appeals her probation

  erred in denying his motion to consolidate
  and dismissing his appeal. Â We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the following authorities: Issue I: Rule 210(h), SCACR (providing the appellate court
  generally will not consider any fact that does not appear in the record on
  appeal); Germain v. Nichol, 278 S.C. 508, 509, 299 S.E.2d 335,

  sufficient record); Issue II:Â  S.C. Code

  the decision of the ALC only if the appellantâ€™s substantive rights have been

  and substantial evidence on the whole record, arbitrary or otherwise
  characterized by an abuse of discretion, or affected by other error of law); Sloan
    v. Friends of Hunley, Inc.,  369 S.C. 20, 25, 630 S.E.2d 474,
  477 (2006) (holding an appellate court generally will not pass on moot and
  academic questions or consider a case where there remains no actual controversy).

text:
<!--

}
-->




THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Alex Claude
      Sheriff, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Edgefield County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
  Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-521
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 9, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General Christina J. Catoe, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V.
  Myers, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Alex Claude Sheriff, appeals his
  convictions for possession of contraband, possession with intent to distribute
  marijuana, and criminal conspiracy.Â  Sheriff argues the trial court erred in
  not allowing him to introduce evidence of his prior guilty pleas. We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Sheriff
  was a prisoner at Trenton Correctional Institution in Edgefield.Â  He was
  working on a road crew assisting with maintenance of an area park.Â  The
  contraband officer for the prison had received information that the road crew
  was bringing drugs into the prison, so he went out to search the park.Â  The
  officer discovered a brown bag containing marijuana and cocaine stuffed between
  the wall and the sink in the menâ€™s bathroom. The officer replaced the package
  with a decoy package and observed the road crew on its next assignment at the
  park.Â  Sheriff and another inmate, Herbert Jones, walked directly to the
  bathroom, and officers found the decoy package stuffed inside Jonesâ€™s boot.Â 
  Jones testified that he and Sheriff were in on the plan together.Â  Sheriff
  eventually told the officers that he was involved with bringing the drugs into
  the prison.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œThe admission or exclusion of evidence is a matter addressed to
  the sound discretion of the trial court[,] and its ruling will not be disturbed
  in the absence of a manifest abuse of discretion accompanied by probable
  prejudice.â€Â  State v. Douglas, 369 S.C. 424, 429, 632 S.E.2d 845, 847-48
  (2006). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
On
  appeal, Sheriff argues the trial court erred in not allowing him to introduce
  evidence of his prior guilty pleas to various criminal charges. The defense
  hoped to offer the evidence to show that Sheriff had pled guilty on previous
  occasions and therefore, if he was guilty of the present charges, would have
  pled guilty as well.[2]Â 
  The trial court did not allow the proffered testimony regarding the disposition
  of the previous charges, because it would improperly bolster his credibility.Â  
According
  to Rule 608(b) of the South Carolina Rules of Evidence, â€œ[s]pecific instances of the conduct of a witness, for the purpose of
  attacking or supporting the witnessâ€™[s] credibility, other than
  conviction of crime as provided in Rule 609, may not be proved by extrinsic
  evidence.â€Â  (emphasis added).Â  The evidence may be introduced on
  cross-examination if probative of truthfulness or untruthfulness.Â  Id.Â  Rule 609 deals strictly with using criminal convictions to impeach a witness.Â  It
  provides that certain convictions are admissible, and notes that there is no
  distinction between a conviction resulting from a trial or a guilty plea.Â  See SCRE 609 (â€œFor the purposes of this rule, a conviction includes a conviction
  resulting from a trial or any type of plea . . . .â€).
Applying
  these rules to the facts of this case, Rule 609 indicates that the disposition
  of Sheriffâ€™s prior charges is irrelevant.Â  It only matters that he was
  ultimately convicted of the charges.Â  Consequently, the evidence is
  inadmissible.Â  See SCRE 402 (â€œEvidence which is not relevant is not
  admissible.â€).
The
  fact that Sheriff previously pled guilty is likewise inadmissible under Rule
  608.Â  If the act of pleading guilty is considered a specific act of conduct, it
  cannot be proved extrinsically to support the witnessâ€™s credibility.Â  That is
  exactly what Sheriff was attempting to do by contrasting his prior behavior
  with his decision to go to trial on the charges in this case.Â  Because
  Sheriffâ€™s guilty pleas were irrelevant under Rule 609 and would improperly
  bolster his credibility under Rule 608, the trial court did not abuse its
  discretion in refusing to admit Sheriffâ€™s testimony about his prior guilty
  pleas.Â Â Â  
Based on the foregoing, the ruling of the circuit court is 
AFFIRMED.
ANDERSON,
  WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.




[1]Â  This case was decided without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.
[2]Â  The proffered testimony consisted of the following
  exchange:

	Q.  Mr. Sheriff, youâ€™ve got the prior convictions
  that we spoke about, correct?
	A.  Yes sir.
	Q.  Were those convictions at trial or did you
  plead guilty?
	A.  I plead guilty.
	Q.  And have you plead not guilty to
  this charge?
	A.  To this charge?
	Q.  The one youâ€™re here for.
	A.  I plead not guilty.
	Q.  Why are you not pleading guilty to
  this charge?
	A.  Because Iâ€™m not guilty of this
  charge.

				Roy Lindsey, pro se, for Appellant.
				Robert W. Jacobs, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Roy Lindsey
  appeals the dismissal of his appeal by the Adminstrative Law Court (ALC).Â  We affirm[1] pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610 (Supp. 2007) (stating an appellate court may reverse or
  modify the decision of the ALC only if the appellantâ€™s substantive rights have
  been prejudiced because the decision is clearly erroneous in light of the
  reliable and substantial evidence on the whole record, arbitrary or otherwise
  characterized by an abuse of discretion, or affected by other error of law); Rule 59, SCALCR (stating the notice of
  appeal from the final decision of an agency to be heard by the ALC must contain
  a brief factual basis for each expresslyÂ  and specifically asserted
  constitutional violation); Rule
  62, SCALCR (stating the ALC may dismiss an appeal for failure to set forth the requisite factual basis for the
  asserted constitutional violations as required by Rule 59, SCALCR); Al-Shabazz v.
    State,Â  338 S.C. 354, 369, 527 S.E.2d 742, 750 (2000) (â€œAn inmate may . . . seek review of [the Department of Correctionsâ€™] final decision in
  an administrative manner under the [Administrative Procedures Act (APA)].
  Placing review of these cases within the ambit of the APA
  will ensure that an inmate receives due process, which consists of notice, a
  hearing, and judicial review.â€). 
AFFIRMED.
SHORT,
  THOMAS, and PIEPER, JJ., concur. 


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
  Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Jane L.
          Williamson, Appellant,
        v.
        Vanguard Homes,
          Inc.; Dryvit Systems, Inc.; Caradon Peachtree, Inc., f/k/a Peachtree Doors,
          Inc.; Moser Design Group, Inc., and Coastal Concepts, Inc., Defendants,
        of whom
        Vanguard Homes,
          Inc., is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Beaufort County
Â Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-In-Equity

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-533
  Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
September 11, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Thomas J. Finn, of Hilton Head, for Appellant.
        Ryan A. Earhart and Robert W. Whelan, of Charleston, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â 
  Jane Williamson sued Vanguard
  Homes, Inc. for alleged defects arising out of the construction of her home on Hilton Head Island.Â  The master granted summary judgment in favor of Vanguard based on the
  statute of repose, and Williamson appealed.Â  
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following authority.
  1. Â As to the issue of whether the master
  in equity improperly shifted the burden of proof:Â  Wilder Corp. v. Wilke,
  330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be
    raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled
  upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€).Â  
2.Â  As to the issue whether the master erred in determining that the statute of repose was not tolled by the
  delivery of the Summons and Complaint to the sheriff.: Hodges v. Rainey,
  341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581 (2000) (â€œWhere the statuteâ€™s language is
  plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and definite meaning the rules of
  statutory interpretation are not needed and the court has no right to impose
  another meaning.â€); Langley v. Pierce, 313 S.C. 401, 404, 438
  S.E.2d 242, 243 (1993) (quoting First United Methodist Church v. U.S. Gypsum
    Co., 882 F.2d 862, 865-66 (4th Cir. 1989)) (the statute of repose â€œis
  typically an absolute time limit beyond which liability no longer exists and is
  not tolled for any reason because to do so would upset the economic balance
  struck by the legislative body.â€).
3.Â 
  As to the issue of whether the master erred in finding that the gross
  negligence exception in the statute of repose was inapplicable Bradley v.
    Doe, 374 S.C. 622, 625, 649 S.E.2d 153, 155 (Ct. App. 2007) (â€œOnce the
  party moving for summary judgment meets the initial burden of showing an
  absence of evidentiary support for the opponentâ€™s case, the opponent cannot
  simply rest on mere allegations or denials contained in the pleadings.Â  Rather,
  the nonmoving party must come forward with specific facts showing there is a genuine
  issue for trial.â€).Â  
AFFIRMED.
HEARN,
  C.J., HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.

title: State v. Woody
text:
<!--
body{
font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;
}
-->



THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Christopher A.
          Woody, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from York County
Â Lee S. Alford, Circuit Court Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-534
  Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
September 11, 2008Â Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief Attorney Joseph L. Savitz, III, of Columbia, for Appellant.
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
          General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant
          Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Kevin S.
          Brackett, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Christopher A. Woody, appeals his
  conviction for murder and possession of a firearm during the commission of a
  violent crime.Â  Â Woody argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for
  mistrial based on the solicitorâ€™s closing statement.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
During
  the Stateâ€™s closing argument at trial, the solicitor made the following
  comment:Â  â€œLadies and Gentlemen, this mountain of evidence that stands before
  you speaks the truth, just as your verdict will speak the truth and thatâ€™s what
  verdict in its original form means, to speak the truth and thatâ€™s what I ask
  you to do.Â  Thatâ€™s what the judge asks you to do, thatâ€™s what South Carolina
  asks you to do and that is your duty today, to speak the truth.â€Â  The defense
  objected to the solicitorâ€™s comments arguing that the remarks gave the jury the
  impression that the judge was aligned with the Stateâ€™s position.Â  The defense
  requested a mistrial, but that request was denied.Â  The judge decided to
  address the question of his neutrality during his charge on the law.Â  At the
  beginning of his charge, the judge instructed:

  The
    court is neutral in any case that comes before it insofar as the court is
    concerned and when the solicitor, I think, mentioned to you in his final
    argument, I believe, that he asked that you render a verdict which speaks the
    truth and he says that he judge wants you to do that.Â  Well, let me say to you
    that you should not infer from that in any way that the judge is not a neutral
    party in this case or is aligned with one side or the other in the case,
    because the judge is not.Â  

LAW/ANALYSIS
On
  appeal, Woody argues the trial court erred in denying his motion for mistrial
  based on the solicitorâ€™s closing statement.Â  We disagree.Â  â€œThe decision to grant or deny a mistrial
  is within the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  A mistrial should only be
  granted when absolutely necessary, and a defendant must show both error and
  resulting prejudice in order to be entitled to a mistrial.â€Â  State v. Ward,
  374 S.C. 606, 612, 649 S.E.2d 145, 148 (Ct. App. 2007) (citations omitted).Â  â€œGenerally, a curative instruction is deemed to have cured any alleged
    error.â€ State v. Patterson, 337 S.C. 215, 226, 522 S.E.2d 845, 850 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Here, the court thoroughly and meticulously instructed the jury to
  disregard any impermissible inference they may have drawn from the solicitorâ€™s
  statement and to remember that the judge serves as a neutral party.Â 
  Consequently, the court did not abuse its discretion in denying Woodyâ€™s motion
  for mistrial. 
AFFIRMED.
Anderson, Williams, and Konduros, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Phillip J.
          Pendergrass, Appellant,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Probation, Pardon , and Parole Services, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Administrative Law Court
  Â John D. Geathers, Administrative Law
Judge

Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-539
  Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed September
17, 2008Â Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Phillip J. Pendergrass, of Bennettsville, pro
          se, for Appellant.
        Tommy Evans, Jr., of Columbia, for
          Respondent.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM:Â  Pendergrass was convicted for
  murder in 1976.Â  He appeals the dismissal of his appeal by the Administrative Law Court. We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following
  authorities: Sullivan v. S. C. Depâ€™t
    of Corrections, 355 S.C. 437, 443 n.
  4, 586 S.E.2d 124, 127 n.4 (2003) (â€œ[A]n inmate has a right of review by the
  AL[C] after a final decision he is ineligible for parole, but that a
  parole-eligible inmate does not have the same right of review after a decision
  denying parole . . . .â€) (emphasis
  in original); Slezak v. S. C. Depâ€™t of Corrections, 361 S.C. 327, 331, 605
  S.E.2d 506, 507 (2004) Â (holding
  while the â€œAL[C] has subject matter
  jurisdiction to hear appeals from the final decision of the [Department of
  Corrections] in a non-collateral or administrative matter,â€ those
  matters can still be summarily dismissed where there is no state-created
  liberty or property interest implicated); Furtick v. S.C.
    Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole & Pardon Servs., 352 S.C. 594, 598 n. 4, 576 S.E.2d 146, 149, n. 4 (2003) (holding
  although an inmate has a liberty interest in parole eligibility, the statute
  governing that process does not create an interest in the granting of parole
  itself).
AFFIRMED.[1]
ANDERSON,
WILLIAMS, and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] We decide this case without oral argument pursuant to
Rule 215, SCACR.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

				In the interest of Lamarcus W., a minor 
				under the age of seventeenÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â

Billy A. Tunstall, Jr., Family Court Judge
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-540
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 17, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Appellate Defender Aileen P. Claire, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and
  Solicitor Jerry W. Peace, of Greenwood, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  The juvenile appeals his
  sentence to the Department of Juvenile
  Justice for an indeterminate amount of time not to exceed his twenty-first
  birthday.Â  He contends the family
  court judge abused his discretion by deviating from the Departmentâ€™s
  recommended sentence.Â  
We affirm pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR, and the following
  authorities: In the Interest of Antonio H., 324 S.C. 120, 122, 477
  S.E.2d 713, 714 (1996) (holding the issue of whether a minor was competent to
  enter a guilty plea was procedurally barred as that issue was not raised at the
  time of the plea, nor was it raised to the judge at the dispositional hearing); Rhoad v. State, 372 S.C. 100, 108, 641 S.E.2d 35, 39 (Ct. App. 2007)
  (holding the length of a sentence is not preserved for appellate review in the
  absence of an objection to the trial judge); In Interest of Arisha K.S.,
  331 S.C. 288, 296, 501 S.E.2d 128, 133 (Ct. App. 1998) (applying general preservation
  rules within the criminal context of a juvenile proceeding, but inviting the
  supreme court to revisit whether such rules should be relaxed because the
  rights of a minor are at stake).
AFFIRMED.

HEARN,
  C.J., HUFF and GEATHERS, JJ., concur.

THIS
  OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS
  PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Shawn M. Reid
      d/b/a Bolt Electric, Appellant,
				v.
				Michael J.
      Carr, Andrea K. Carr, and Kessler Construction Company, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal from Beaufort County
Curtis L. Coltrane, Master-In-Equity
Unpublished Opinion No. 2008-UP-541
Submitted September 2, 2008 â€“ Filed
  September 17, 2008Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Ehrick K. Haight, Jr., of Hilton Head Island, for Appellant.
				Terry A. Finger and Tyler A. Melnick, both of Hilton Head Island,
  for Respondents.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  Shawn M. Reid appeals the masterâ€™s grant
  of summary judgment in favor of the Carrs based on the failure to serve a
  mechanicâ€™s lien.Â  We affirm.[1]
FACTS
  AND PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Reid
  performed electrical work on a home being built by the Carrs.Â Â Â  Reid filed a
  mechanicâ€™s lien against the property.Â  Reid attempted to serve the Carrs by
  leaving the notice and certificate of lien with Carlos Garcia, a painting
  subcontractor present on the property.Â  Reid had the Sheriffâ€™s Office in Oakland County, Michigan attempt to serve the Carrs at their residence in that state.Â  When
  the Sheriffâ€™s Office was unable to serve the Carrs, Reid filed affidavits of
  non-service approximately 109 days after the last date of work on the subject
  property.Â  
The
  master granted the Carrâ€™s motion for summary judgment for lack of effective
  service under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 29-5-90, the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  Reid
  appeals.
STANDARD
  OF REVIEW
Reid
  argues that the master erred in granting summary judgment to the Carrs, because
  there were genuine issues of material fact regarding service of the mechanicâ€™s
  lien.Â  However, the record shows that the facts are essentially undisputed.Â 
  The question presented to the master was whether the facts set forth satisfied
  the service requirements found in the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â Â  â€œWhen an
  appeal involves stipulated or undisputed facts, an appellate court is free to
  review whether the trial court properly applied the law to those facts.â€Â  Duke
    Power Co. v. Laurens Elec. Co-op., Inc., 344 S.C. 101, 104, 543 S.E.2d 560,
  561 (Ct. App. 2000).Â Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Reidâ€™s
  first argument involves service of the notice and certificate of lien on
  Garcia.Â  Reid contends that Garcia, a laborer of a subcontractor, constitutes a
  â€œperson in possessionâ€ as contemplated by the mechanicâ€™s lien statute.Â  The
  statute provides that a mechanicâ€™s lien shall
  be dissolved unless the person desiring the lien serves the owner or â€œperson in
  possessionâ€ of the property with a notice and certificate of lien.Â  S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 29-5-90 (2007).Â  The only
  case touching on this issue is Stovall Bldg. Supplies, Inc. v. Mottet,
  305 S.C. 28, 406 S.E.2d 176 (Ct. App. 1990).Â  In Stovall, the court
  determined that service of a mechanicâ€™s lien on a subdivision security guard
  did not constitute service on a â€œperson in possessionâ€ as contemplated by the
  statute.Â  Id. at 33, 406 S.E.2d at 179.Â  The court stated â€œ[t]he
  security guard was not a responsible person living in the [ownerâ€™s] home.â€Â  Id.Â  Likewise, Garcia, as the employee of a subcontractor, was not a responsible
  person living in the home.Â  Therefore, service on Garcia would not constitute
  service on a â€œperson in possessionâ€ and would not be sufficient to preserve the
  mechanicâ€™s lien.
Reid
  further argues the affidavits of non-service that were filed outside the ninety-day
  statutory period are valid to preserve the lien.Â  The statute sets a ninety-day
  time limit after the last date of labor or furnishing of materials to
  accomplish service.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  29-5-90 (2007).Â  The statute contemplates that service may not always be
  possible.Â  Id.Â  â€œ[I]n the event neither the owner nor the person in
  possession can be located after diligent search, and this fact is verified by
  affidavit of the sheriff or his deputy, the lien may be preserved by filing the
  statement together with the affidavit.â€Â  Id. Â The statute does not however provide for an
  extension of time for attempted service or the subsequent filing of affidavits
  of non-service.Â  To read a vague grace period into the statute would go against
  the general policy of interpreting statutes according to their plain meaning.Â  See Mun. Assâ€™n of S.C. v. AT&T Commcâ€™ns of S. States, Inc., 361 S.C.
  576, 580, 606 S.E.2d 468, 470 (2004) (â€œ[T]he words of the statute must be given their plain and
  ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or
  expand the statute's operation.â€).Â  Accordingly, the master correctly applied
  the statute under these circumstances to conclude that the filing of affidavits
  of non-service outside the ninety-day time limit did not preserve the lien. 
Finally,
  Reid argues that service on the Kessler Construction Company Â as general
  contractors satisfied the requirement of service on the owners.Â  Nothing in the
  statute provides for such substituted service, and the relevant affidavit of
  service only indicates service on Kessler Construction as a party, not as agent
  for the Carrs.
Based on all of the foregoing, the ruling of the master is 
AFFIRMED.

ANDERSON, WILLIAMS,
  and KONDUROS, JJ., concur.


[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decide this case without oral argument pursuant
  to Rule 215, SCACR.

THIS OPINION HAS
  NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY
  PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

	
		
			
				Berkeley Hall Club, Inc., Respondent,
				v.
				Fred I. Palmer, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Beaufort County
Curtis L.
  Coltrane, Special Circuit Judge
Unpublished Opinion
  No.Â  2008-UP-542
Heard September
  16, 2008 â€“ Filed September 18, 2008
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Roberts Vaux and
  Douglas L. Novak, both of Bluffton, for Appellant.
				Terry A. Finger,
  of Hilton Head, for Respondent.
			
		
	

PER CURIAM:Â  This
  appeal involves a dispute over past due assessment fees.Â  On appeal, Fred I.
  Palmer (Palmer) argues (1) the trial court erred in failing to provide sufficient
  factual findings to support its conclusions; (2) the trial court erred in
  failing to comply with Rule 52(a), SCRCP; and (3) the trial court erred in
  failing to provide factual findings in its order denying appellantâ€™s Rule 59(e)
  motion to alter or amend the judgment. Â The issues on appeal are procedural and
  do not challenge the substantive conclusions reached by the trial court.Â 
  Moreover, at oral argument, appellant conceded that any attempt to amend the
  pleadings was abandoned at trial.
We affirm the order of the trial court pursuant to Rule 220(b), SCACR,
  and the following authorities: As to issues 1 and 2: Â Rule 52(a), SCRCP
  (requiring the trial court to find the facts specially and state separately its
  conclusions of law thereon); Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403
  S.E.2d 122, 123-24 (1991) (â€œWhere a trial court substantially complies with
  Rule 52(a) and adequately states the basis for the result it reaches, the
  appellate court should not vacate the trial courtâ€™s judgment for lack of an
  explicit or specific factual finding.â€); In the Matter of the Treatment and
    Care of Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 133, 568 S.E.2d 338, 343 (2002) (â€œWe do
  not require a lower court to set out findings on all the myriad factual
  questions arising in a particular case.â€); Biales v. Young, 315 S.C.
  166, 168, 432 S.E.2d 482, 484 (1993) (noting failure to challenge a ruling of
  the lower court renders the issue abandoned and precludes consideration on
  appeal); Charleston Lumber Co., Inc. v. Miller Hous. Corp., 338 S.C.
  171, 175, 525 S.E.2d 869, 871 (2000) (finding an
  unchallenged ruling, right or wrong, is the law of the case). Â As to
  issue 3: Rule 52(a), SCRCP (stating findings of fact and conclusions of law are
  not necessary on various motions).Â  
AFFIRMED.
SHORT, THOMAS, and PIEPER, J.J., concur.

PER CURIAM:Â  Â 
  We affirm[1] the order of the special referee pursuant to Rule 220(b)(2), SCACR and the
  following authorities: Butler
    Contracting, Inc. v. Court Street, LLC, 369 S.C. 121, 127, 631
  S.E.2d 252, 255-56 (2006) (finding the foreclosure of a mechanicsâ€™ lien is an action at law.Â  In an action at law, tried without a jury, an
  appellate court will not disturb the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact unless they
  are wholly unsupported by the evidence or unless it clearly appears the
  findings are controlled by an error
  of law); West v. Newberry Elec. Co-op.,
  357 S.C. 537, 543, 593 S.E.2d 500, 503 (Ct. App. 2004) (finding issue that is
  neither addressed by trial court in final order nor raised by way of Rule
  59(e), SCRCP, motion is not preserved for review).  Further, we grant
  the guardian ad litemâ€™s petition to be relieved. 
AFFIRMED.
HEARN, C.J., CURETON and
  GOOLSBY, A.J.J. Concur.



[1]Â  Because oral argument would not aid the court in
  resolving the issues on appeal, we decide this case without oral argument
pursuant to Rule 215, SCACR.

PER CURIAM: Micah

  pursuant to Ex Parte Cauthen, 291 S.C. 465, 354 S.E.2d 381 (1987), we
